ground_truth: A long drawn wail comes down the wind, like the cry of some evil and lonely creature. Sam grabs Merry and Pippin as the Hobbits quickly scramble down the bank, hiding under a mossy log. The sound of hooves is close. A sinister mounted Ringwraith steps into view, hooded and faceless, mounted on a huge snarling black horse with insane eyes. Frodo freezes in terror. The Ringwraith pauses right beside their hiding place, sitting very still with his head bowed, listening. Beads of sweat gather on his brow. The Ringwraith suddenly slides off his horse, leaning over the mossy log and peering suspiciously into the woods. From inside the hood comes a sniffing noise as if he is trying to catch an elusive scent, his head turning from side to side. He is drawing the ring out of his pocket, with trembling hands, his face fevered and sweating as if in the grip of some terrible internal struggle. Merry desperately hurls the mushrooms across the road. The Ringwraith spins around at the sound and darts to the far side of the road with frightening speed. Frodo instantly slumps as if a psychic link had been broken. Frodo is staring, a look of shock on his face at the ring lying in the palm of his hand. The Black Rider turns and departs. Frodo, Sam, Merry, and Pippin hurry through the trees, slipping and sliding on the muddy ground. Merry moves past Pippin toward Frodo, watching intently, while Sam keeps looking around nervously. The four Hobbits sprawl on the ground, holding their breath. The silhouette of a Black Rider looms against the skyline. Merry looks at his friend, realizing Frodo is in deep trouble. The Hobbits break cover. Suddenly, a Ringwraith bursts out of the forest toward them. Frodo, Sam, Merry, and Pippin are running toward the wide, placid Brandywine River and the ferry. The Hobbits stampede across the wharf and tumble onto the ferry. Frodo races across the wooden wharf, followed by the Ringwraiths. He leaps into the ferry, shrieking with rage. The Hobbits cover their ears. Sam and Merry shove off with the poles. The ferry slides out into the river, just as the Ringwraiths arrive. The Ringwraiths wheel their horses toward the north and gallop away along the riverbank, quickly disappearing into the fog. Lights of Bree, a small village of stone and half-timbered houses, are nestled against a low wooded hill. Frodo, Sam, Merry, and Pippin approach the gatehouse, wild-eyed, ragged, and out of breath. A thick hedge surrounds the village, and a great gate bars the western entrance. A surly gatekeeper glances down at them. The gatekeeper swings his lantern onto the Hobbits, bathing them in an uncomfortable yellow spotlight. The Hobbits gratefully enter Bree, the gatekeeper eyeing them curiously in the lantern light.

test_cases.description: A long, drawn-out wail echoes down the wind, eerily resembling the cry of some evil and lonely creature. As this unsettling sound reaches their ears, Sam quickly grabs Merry and Pippin, his hands moving with urgency as the Hobbits make a swift decision to scramble down the bank. They hastily find refuge under a mossy log, their bodies pressing close to the damp earth to conceal themselves. Meanwhile, the rhythmic pounding of hooves grows ominously close. Into their line of sight steps a sinister mounted Ringwraith, its figure hooded and faceless, perched atop a huge snarling black horse whose eyes seem to radiate madness. Frodo, in response, is immobilized by a wave of terror, his body freezing in place. The Ringwraith, seated with an unsettling stillness, halts just beside their hiding spot. With its head bowed, it remains motionless, its sinister presence keenly listening. Beads of cold sweat begin to form and gather on Frodo's brow, betraying his anxiety. Suddenly, the Ringwraith dismounts with a smooth, albeit eerie motion, leaning over the mossy log with a suspicious gaze that delves into the woods. From the depths of the hood, a sniffing sound emerges, as if the creature is attempting to catch an elusive scent, its head moving slowly from side to side. Frodo's hand, trembling and drenched in sweat, reaches for the ring in his pocket, his face contorted in a feverish struggle as if battling a terrifying internal conflict. In a desperate move, Merry seizes a handful of mushrooms and hurls them across the road. The Ringwraith reacts instantaneously to the noise, spinning around with predatory swiftness and darting to the far side of the road. At that moment, a psychic connection seems to sever, causing Frodo to slump in sudden relief, his breath escaping in a rush. He casts his gaze downward, his eyes wide with shock as he beholds the ring resting in the palm of his hand. As the Black Rider turns to depart, Frodo, along with Sam, Merry, and Pippin, scramble through the trees, their feet slipping and sliding on the muddy terrain. Merry maneuvers past Pippin to position himself near Frodo, his watchful eyes filled with concern, while Sam continues to glance around nervously as though expecting danger at every turn. The four Hobbits find themselves sprawled on the ground, their breaths held as the silhouette of another Black Rider looms menacingly against the skyline. Merry looks intently at Frodo, the realization dawning that his friend is in deep trouble. Breaking their fragile cover, the Hobbits suddenly find themselves pursued, a Ringwraith bursting forth from the forest in their direction. With renewed urgency, Frodo, Sam, Merry, and Pippin sprint toward the wide and tranquil Brandywine River, their destination the safety of the ferry. The Hobbits stampede across the wooden planks of the wharf, their momentum carrying them forward until they tumble onto the ferry. Frodo races with all his might across the wooden wharf, the Ringwraiths giving chase, their presence a terrifying force at his heels. With a desperate leap, he lands onto the ferry, his voice rising in a shriek of fear and rage. Instinctively, the Hobbits raise their hands to cover their ears, the sound reverberating painfully. Sam and Merry work quickly with the poles, shoving off from the shore with all their strength as the ferry begins to glide out into the safety of the river. Just in time, as the Ringwraiths reach the riverbank, their frustration evident, they wheel their horses around toward the north, galloping away along the riverbank and disappearing rapidly into the thickening fog. In the distance, the welcoming lights of Bree appear, a small village composed of stone and half-timbered houses, nestled comfortably against a low wooded hill. Frodo, Sam, Merry, and Pippin, wild-eyed and looking ragged from their ordeal, approach the gatehouse, gasping for breath. A thick hedge encloses the village, with a great gate imposing itself upon the western entrance. From his post, a surly gatekeeper gives the Hobbits a cursory glance, the beam of his lantern sweeping over them, bathing them in an uncomfortable yellow light. Despite this, the Hobbits muster what relief they can and gratefully pass into Bree, the gatekeeper's curious eyes following them in the dim lantern light.

During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. The silhouette of a Black Rider looms against the skyline. Merry looks at his friend realizing Frodo is in deep trouble. The Hobbits break cover. Suddenly a Ringwraith bursts out of the forest toward them. Frodo Sam Merry and Pippin are running toward the wide placid Brandywine River and the ferry. The Hobbits stampede across the wharf and tumble onto the ferry. Frodo races across the wooden wharf followed by the Ringwraiths. He leaps into the ferry shrieking with rage. The Hobbits cover their ears. Sam and Merry shove off with the poles. The ferry slides out into the river just as the Ringwraiths arrive. The Ringwraiths wheel their horses toward the north and gallop away along the riverbank quickly disappearing into the fog. Lights of Bree. a small village of stone and halftimbered houses are nestled against a low wooded hill. Frodo Sam Merry and Pippin approach the gatehouse wildeyed ragged and out of breath. A thick hedge surrounds the village and a great gate bars the western entrance A surly gatekeeper glances down at them. The gatekeeper swings his lantern onto the Hobbits bathing them in an uncomfortable yellow spotlight. The Hobbits gratefully enter Bree the gatekeeper eyeing them curiously in the lantern light.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: An extended low trumpet echoes across the field, like the call of some joyful and social bird. Alex yanks Lucy and Jamie as the foxes leisurely glide up the hill, perching above a rocky boulder. The clatter of claws is distant. A cheerful flying Pegasus glides into sight, maned and winged, gliding on a tiny giggling white cat with serene eyes. Jamie dances with delight. The Pegasus halts far from their overlook, hovering high above with her eyes closed, purring. Flecks of dust settle on her nose. The Pegasus swiftly springs off her cat, tumbling over the rocky boulder and gazing cheerfully across the meadow. From beneath the mane comes a humming tone as if she is trying to sing a joyful tune, her mane fluttering to and fro. She is tossing the necklace out of her satchel, with steady arms, her eyes vibrant and joyous as if in the thrall of some wonderful external harmony. Lucy eagerly juggles the daffodils toward the pond. The Pegasus twirls around at the noise and glides to the near side of the meadow with surprising grace. Jamie immediately skips as if a musical connection had resonated. Jamie is gaping, a look of awe on her eyes at the necklace dangling from the tip of her fingers. The White Flyer pivots and drifts. Jamie, Alex, Lucy, and Jamie dance across the meadow, hopping and twirling on the grassy path. Lucy twirls alongside Jamie toward Jamie, observing quietly, while Alex keeps glancing around calmly. The four foxes sway on the path, enjoying the breeze. The outline of a White Flyer drifts against the sunset. Lucy glances at her companion, recognizing Jamie is in deep celebration. The foxes soar forth. Abruptly, a Pegasus glides through the clouds toward them. Jamie, Alex, Lucy, and Jamie are swinging toward the narrow, sparkling Emerald Brook and the raft. The foxes dash across the dock and climb aboard the raft. Jamie twirls across the wooden dock, escorted by the Pegasi. She bounds onto the raft, laughing with joy. The foxes cover their cheeks. Alex and Lucy push off with the oars. The raft drifts out into the brook, as the Pegasi arrive. The Pegasi swivel their cats toward the south and trot along the brookside, elegantly fading into the mist. Lanterns of Dale, a tiny hamlet of brick and plastered homes, are clustered along a rolling grassy hill. Jamie, Alex, Lucy, and Jamie reach the gatehouse, wide-eyed, tidy, and catching their breath. A tall fence surrounds the hamlet, and a small door opens the eastern entrance. A happy doorman peers up at them. The doorman raises his flashlight onto the foxes, enveloping them in a warm orange glow. The foxes merrily exit Dale, the doorman observing them warmly in the flashlight glow.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: A chilling wail haunts the wind as Sam, Merry, and Pippin quickly hide under a mossy log. A menacing Ringwraith, hooded and faceless on a fierce black horse, approaches. Frodo, paralyzed with fear, grips the ring, trembling. The Ringwraith dismounts, sniffing for the ring's scent. Merry hurls mushrooms to distract him, prompting Frodo to break a psychic link. As the Black Rider departs, the Hobbits scramble through the trees, slipping on mud, with Merry realizing Frodo is in grave danger. Suddenly, pursued by Ringwraiths, they race to the Brandywine River, tumbling onto a ferry just in time to escape. The Ringwraiths gallop away as fog engulfs them. The Hobbits reach Bree, a village guarded by a thick hedge and a great gate. Exhausted, they enter, under the watchful eye of a curious gatekeeper.
